all_paragraphs: Dates and time are integral to any programming application — it is the driver of movement and a stable indicator of where we are on the universe’s huge time-line. Every sub-field within computer science — from data science and AI to designing webpages — requires an understanding of dealing with dates.

Because they’re so messy (simple task: try to make a program that finds the date 64 days after date n without any external libraries), with complexities abound — the length of dates, leap years, sub-objects nested within parent ones — when dealing with datetime objects, you must know these 6 functions and methods.
Note: This article discusses datetime in Python.

Converting strings to dates is common — to access the properties of a datetime object, the string representing the date must be converted to one. Unfortunately, datasets or other date sources almost never come with datetime objects that can be handily accessed. The best library for converting strings to dates is dateutil, which can automatically infer the location of days, months, and years, which need to be specified with other libraries.

dateutil can accommodate a wide variety of dates, where each of the commands one each line automatically infers the location of objects and yields the same result (datetime.datetime(2040, 7, 3, 0, 0)):

If a human can tell the date from a string, then dateutil can. Using this library, you can avoid the annoying date-object mapping that you would need to perform through conventional datetime-converting methods. This is especially helpful when not all dates come in the same format, often the case with real-world data.
To access the current time, use datetime.datetime.now(). This returns a datetime object returning what time it is in your region, down to the microsecond.

An alternative is datetime.datetime.today(), which returns the same information but with less precision. This may be more suitable in cases of high traffic where the slight improvement in computation time could prove valuable.

Calendar is a library built on top of datetime, and provides handy calendar-related functions, helping bypass needing to manually keep track of leap years and the number of days in a month. In order to access iterative functions, a Calendar object must first be created.
The parameter firstweekday is set to 0, indicating Monday, but can also be set to 6 (Sunday) or any day in between.
Consider .itermonthdates(), which takes in a month and a year and returns an iterator which contains all the dates in the month, including any before and after it needed to complete a full week.

Arrow is a Python library whose humanize() attribute stands out. This method allows humans to interact with and interpret date objects more seamlessly. First, an Arrow object must be created (datetime objects can be accommodated and converted into Arrow objects).
Calling time.humanize() will yield a string with a human-readable message describing how long ago time was from right now.

One can imagine that this feature would be especially helpful to UI-designing developers, who could use it to display messages like “Josh sent this message two minutes ago” or “You edited this document a year ago”. Arrow can also handle dates in the future.
